paragraph.paragraph: EiffelEnvision projects are like most Visual Studio .NET language-base projects, such as Visual C#, Visual Basic .NET and Visual J#, but with a flair of Eiffel. Just like those formentioned languages, EiffelEnvision projects, predominatly, vxconFolder-BasedReference-BasedProjects 0 manage files , and directly reflect and underlying file system. However, there are fundamental differences between EiffelEnvision projects and other language projects, even those that vxconFolder-BasedReference-BasedProjects 0 manage files .

EiffelEnvision projects, denoted by the ../../../images/icons/project.ico icon in the vxurfSolutionExplorerDialog 0 Solution Explorer , are segregated into four very disinct segments, sectioned beneath the EiffelEnvision project node.
../../../images/icons/references.ico project.xmlreferencesReferences
../../../images/icons/project_items.ico project.xmlproject_itemsProject Items
../../../images/icons/eiffel_libraries.ico project.xmleiffel_librariesEiffel Libraries

Each section is disparate from each other. Only the project.xmlproject_itemsProject Items and project.xmleiffel_librariesEiffel Libraries nodes base any resemblence to one another.

The References of an EiffelEnvision project contains all of the project's component references, added to a project when a project is created using one of the urlEiffelEnvision Project Templates or when explicitly vxtskAddingRemovingProjectReferences 0 Adding References . For more information about the References section of an EiffelEnvision project, see reference_node.xmlReferences Nodes.

Eiffel's principle system of reuse is through source code reuse, unlike the .NET Framework's binary reuse through assemblies. url*Eiffel for .NET still maintains reuse through source code, as Eiffel does, but also permits binary reuse through assemblies and url*Precompiled Libraries. EiffelEnvision supports all of these concepts, but unlike other environments, used in conjunction with Eiffel or Eiffel for .NET, there is no implicit, clean separation is made between project files/source code and reused Eiffel libraries source code. In url*Eiffel for .NET further separation is required between source code reuse and binary reuse, using assemblies.

EiffelEnvision remedies this integral issue with a very distinct and clean separartion between component (assembly) referencs, project files, where it be a bitmap resource or Eiffel url*class source file, and Eiffel source libraries. As forementioned, EiffelEnvision includes a project.xmlreferencesReferences section for each of it's projects. Contained within this section are all component and url*Precompiled Library references for that project. url*Project Items and url*Eiffel Libraries support the separation of project-specific Eiffel url*classes and files and Eiffel library url*class source files, respectivley. Although the separation between url*Project Items and url*Eiffel Libraries is not strictly enforce by EiffelEnvision, for other tool compatablity reasons, it is recommended that all EiffelEnvision projects adhear to this convention. Clean separation will assist in the future maintainance or adoption of your projects, by other developers. Because Eiffel source files are include using url*clusters, there will be no confusion as to what files are project files and what files are Eiffel library sources.
